dk.statsbiblioteket.util
Class LineReader

java.lang.Object
  dk.statsbiblioteket.util.LineReader
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.DataInput, java.io.DataOutput
@QAInfo(state=QA_NEEDED,
        level=NORMAL)
public class LineReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.DataInput, java.io.DataOutput

A Java NIO based high-performance, large file-size enabled, random seek capable line reader. Use only for good.

The reader assumes UTF-8 encoding when performing String-related operations. It is substantially faster than RandomAccessFile (about a factor 5 for most operations). It can be used as a replacement for RandomAccessFile.

Important: writeUTF is not supported. This is because the relevant converter method DataOutputStream.writeUTF(String, DataOutput) is package private.

This class is not synchronised.

Constructor Detail

LineReader

public LineReader(java.io.File file,
                  java.lang.String mode)
           throws java.io.IOException
Connects to the given file with the given mode. This corresponds to RandomAccessFile(File, String).

Parameters:
file - the file to connect to.
mode - the mode to use. Valid values are
"r": read-only.
"rw": read and write.
"rws": read and write and synchronize after each write. "rwd": read and write and synchronize after each write.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the file coult not be accessed.
Method Detail

setBufferSize

public void setBufferSize(int bufferSize)
                   throws java.io.IOException
The buffer size affects performance greatly.
Set this low (hundreds of bytes) if the file is large, the access very random and the reads small.
Set this high (thousands of bytes) if the file is medium, the access clustered and/or the reads are large.
Set this very high (the file size) if the file is small.

Parameters:
bufferSize - the size of the buffer.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if an I/O exception occured while changing the buffer.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.io.IOException
Reset the position in the file to 0 and free any open file handles. Later access to the file is allowed, as it is automatically opened. This is equivalent to close().

Throws:
java.io.IOException - if the file could not be closed.

readLine

public java.lang.String readLine()
                          throws java.io.IOException
Reads a line from the file, assuming UTF-8 and 0x0A as line break. Note that this differs from RandomAccessFile.readLine() with regards to encoding and line breaks.

Specified by:
readLine in interface java.io.DataInput
Returns:
the text at the current position, until the next line break. If the line is the last in the file, all characters up to the end of the file will be returned.
Throws:
java.io.EOFException - if no characters could be read.
java.io.IOException - if a line could not be read.

binaryLineSearch

public long binaryLineSearch(java.util.Comparator<java.lang.String> comparator,
                             java.lang.String query)
                      throws java.io.IOException
Find the start-position of a line matching the given query. A binary-search is used, thus requiring the user of the LineReader to maintain specific structure and a matching comparator.

The expected structure is UTF-8 with new-line "\n" as line-delimiters. As the byte 0x0A for new-line is never part of a valid multi-byte UTF-8 character this should pose no problems.

Searching for an empty line is not supported. Escaping on line breaks is the responsibility of the user.

Recommendation: Call setBufferSize(int) with an amount corresponding to the line-length. Keep in mind that binary searching often result in a lot of lookups around the same position at the end of the search, choosing the average length of a single line as the buffer size is probably too small. If the lines are short (< 20 chars), use a value such as 400. If the lines are long (~100 chars), go for 1000 or 2000. If the lines are very long (1000+), consider 4000 or 8000. These are soft guidelines as the best values are also dependend of the characteristica of the underlying storage: SSDs will normally benefit the most from relatively small values, while conventional harddisks are better off with larger values as the minimize seeks.

Parameters:
comparator - used for the binary search. If the comparator is null, the default String.compareTo is used. The comparator will be used with compare(query, line).
query - the element to look for. If comparator is null, this should be a full line.
Returns:
the index of the query or (-(insertion point) - 1) if it could not be found.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if reads of the underlying file failed.
